ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Ariel Russ  Ariel Russ
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Offered help to our group work. Thank you!
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Ariel also graded my assignments and answered my questions.
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Ariel was a good TA. She gave us helpful comments for our final project and was available for questions.
Instructor: Ariel Russ  I was mostly engaging with Oscar
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar Benjamin
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Benjamin Oscar - especially in consultation of our final project
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Quik and clear feedback to our questions. Thank you!
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar Benjamin
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar was the TA on my final project. Not only was he helpful in enforcing deadlines but he was very knowledgeable about our topic.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar graded the majority of my assignments, and was a TA facilitator for the final project.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar was great!
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar

Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar was a great TF and was always willing to make time to meet with project groups and offer advice and suggestions to improve our understanding and opportunities to learn.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  I was mostly engaging with Oscar

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Ariel Russ  Less interaction with her
Instructor: Ariel Russ  She was a fair and good TA, no improvements suggested
Instructor: Ariel Russ  I did not have much interaction with Ariel over the course of the class. Her grading system seemed fair.
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Ariel was always accessible and was quick at responding to questions. She also was good at explaining the ideas we discussed in class.

Instructor: Ariel Russ  Both Oscar and Ariel brought a lot of knowledge and experience from working in CSR. I'd prefer to have more feedback on assignments to know where we could have improved - feedback was available in the Five Forces and Toys in China assignments but not the Palm Oil.
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Would be useful to see grading rubric (either before or after grades are submitted)
Instructor: Ariel Russ  Ariel was quick to respond to questions and very helpful.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Very knowledgeable and clearly passionate about this topic, but could be more transparent about grading
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Gave great feedback on questions regarding our final project and forwarded valuable resources/references.

Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar is clearly very knowledgeable about corporate social responsibility. On some of the assignments, his grading rubric seemed to be based more on whether you wrote an answer the exact right way, rather than whether you understood the concept. As a result, people seemed to do much worse on assignments that Oscar graded than on other assignments.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Strength: smart and accessible

Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar was very helpful at outlining elements of the course and highlighting what was important. I think that the HW grading scale between him and Ariel was not always calibrated so carefully. Oscar was helpful at providing tips and strategies for working with our client during the final project.

Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Both Oscar and Ariel brought a lot of knowledge and experience from working in CSR. I'd prefer to have more feedback on assignments to know where we could have improved - feedback was available in the Five Forces and Toys in China assignments but not the Palm Oil.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Would be useful to see grading rubric (either before or after grades are submitted)

Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Oscar was helpful. He responded to my questions and went out of his way to offer to help explain additional questions in the future. He did have a reputation for being a harder grader but that's not necessarily a bad thing.
Instructor: Oscar Ellory Benjamin  Very honest, frank and helpful comments about the coursework and group projects. Always approachable and happy to meet for help.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The class content is too broad and cursory to be useful to students who have had some previous exposure to corporate sustainability. There wasn't very much "strategy" to this class, and it was pretty disorganized.

The class was very disorganized. This was the case for many areas of the course but i'll provide a couple examples. 1) timelines were not clearly thought out as multiple assignments were due on the same day or within just a few days, 2) information wasn't distributed in a timely manner - I can think of at least twice we were given less than a week to complete or study for assignments that had a large impact on our grade because material wasn't circulated early enough in advance, including subjects for the midterm. 3) There wasn't a feel of cohesion between the lectures in the course, it just seemed like we were taught something completely different from one lecture to the next, the professors often were unable to complete a large amount of material in the slideshows because time ran out. 4) Questions we were asked to answer were very vague, sometimes with absolutely no guidance (such as debate criteria), this would be fine but the grading rubrics were then very picky, causing a situation where we either got lucky and hit the right expectations or completely missed them.
Course is not practical. Very little useful information.

A large portion of the course was rooted in theory and frameworks for academic thinking, at the expense of strategies for practitioners to actually implement solutions to the challenges outlined in the class. Ben spent an undue amount of time talking about FSC and SFI, the spotted owl, and legality verification. That content certain deserves a few minutes of class discussion, but it would have been far preferable to have more lectures from Marian, or guest lectures from real practitioners rather than abstract concepts and tenuous connections to real-world application.
Marian is an amazing instructor. And she is so nice and really cares about the material! Cashore was really hard to follow in this class.

The course was interesting. As it was a survey course, I feel like I wouldn't be able to immediately explain the steps a company should take to practice good environmental management. Perhaps that is due to the different nature of various businesses.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: - Different dives into the case studies through assignments, debates and class discussions. - Really enjoyed the final project as it was an unfamiliar industry for me but I ended feeling I gained important understanding through the research and discussion with team members - Assa Abbloy field trip
I really enjoyed the field trip and the beginning material of the course (such as five forces). Those seemed clearly taught to me.

Some of the assignments were interesting to think through. Preparing for debates/cases and final presentation was also valuable to an extent, though more direction would have been useful in both cases.
Combining a lot of interesting topics.

The best aspects of this course were Marian's information, the field trip and the group project. I believe that the group project was most beneficial because I had an actual client, and if this was not the case, I do not believe that this project would have been as valuable.

The class provided a good introduction to corporate sustainability. The cases were one of the best aspects of the course, they really helped us understand how to apply the concepts we learned in real circumstances/ business settings.
Practical foundation information on CSR and its links to the environmental world.
The field trip was great. It would be nice to go on more field trips.
The lectures in this class were great, and the guest speakers were excellent.
I enjoyed some of the problem sets, the field trip, and some of the guest speakers.
Field trip and guest lectures.
The guest lecturers and Marian's lectures. I also really enjoyed the student presentations and debates.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: - Would have liked to see marketing/ consumer facing aspects of corporate sustainability discussed more throughout the class. - There was a good mix of theory and examples of practice but maybe the structure of the class made it difficult to connect/analyse the two against each other. Only through the final project did I feel I had the chance to make good use of integration. - It would be great if the content of class could be structured in such a way that it produced bundles of 'toolkits' instead of just frameworks of thinking and exposure to different cases.

Aside from the disorganization, the material was very hypothetical and sometimes very difficult to comprehend. The slides were not very useful to study, as they often said one or two key phrases rather than explaining them and summarizing key points. If you didn't grasp exactly what the professor was saying the keywords meant nothing to you.
The design of the course - lectures, materials, and how to relate it to real practice of corporate environmental management.
Coordination between the professors to form a sense of cohesion between their ideas and lectures.
Cap the class at half the current size.

This course was a two-teacher course, which had its benefits and its drawbacks. While it was interesting to look at different aspects of corporate sustainability, the class was often disorganized and the expectations for students were not clearly set out. Often, many things were told at the last minute, which made it difficult to produce the work that the professors were expecting. Some of the slides needed updating and proofreading. This class was very much about the theory, and not about how these ideas are applied or actual strategies about how to apply them. Additionally, it would have been better to go more into depth in some of the topics, to better understand how they could be applied, rather than the philosophy. I went to a lecture (on sustainable buildings and the bottom line) that covered almost all of the important elements we learned in class from the beginning of the course through the midterm in about an hour and half. I think that if some of the pace was faster in the beginning, there would be plenty of time to learn about implementation skills in the course. The philosophy/policy part of the class did not have very many examples (only the FSC vs SFI) and never really reached any conclusion. It was only in speaking to Cashore one-on-one that I truly understood what he was talking about. I know that the debates and case studies were designed to create discussion and analyze the readings,but they were a bit repetitive and were not always successful in illuminating the reading. I tihnk small group activities may be a strategy to work into the class in the future. The group projects are the culminating project of this course, and while mine was very good, because it had an actual client and material that related to the course content, i do not believe that this was the case for everyone. This is really a lost opportunity because there is a lot of potential for learning through the project. The visiting professors were interesting, and brought a more applied or experiential understanding to the topics we discussed in class.
Ben Cashore's lectures were far too theoretical, and in my opinion, somewhat disorganized. I enrolled in the course for more applicable skills. Less political theory, more real-life scenarios.
There was a juxtaposition between Marian's practical approach to the subject matter and Ben's academic approach. Sometimes this difference was more jarring than complementary.
The linkages between the two professor's lectures were not immediately obvious. I was left confused after a few of Ben Cashore's lectures.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, although gaps were felt. Same notes as question 18.
n/a
There was not a lab: discussion section.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fits great as I wanted to focus on corporate sustainability both academically and professionally. Wanted to have an understanding of how corporate sustainability was viewed and practiced here in the US, including exposure to trends and standards. Felt like overall this expectation was met by the course. My understanding of corporate sustainability has expanded.

I thought this course would fit better into my energy-focused program, with strategies on how to engage firms to reduce energy consumption and generally make their business practices more environmentally sustainable. I was surprised at the lack of energy-related content in the course.
Gave me an idea whether I like environmental business and whether I would like to seek for job in this field.
I worked in corporate strategy from the non profit side. I am in the process of switching to the private sector and this class provided valuable strategies from the corporate perspective.
My goal is to work at the intersection of business and the environment, this class provided many frameworks as to how this could fit in.
I am interested in corporate sustainability and public-private partnerships and this was a good introduction class for these topics.
For me, this was one of the most important foundational classes at FES, since I have almost no business background, but am considering a pivot towards private sector sustainability initiatives.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Same as question 20.
I wanted an introduction to the private sector environmental field. To gain insight into their motivations and though processes; what they value in the environmental movement.
I thought I would learn practical concepts and tools to help in my professional career.
See above answer.
Had little knowledge on it before, would like to see if I am interested.
To prepare for an internship in the private sector.
I wanted to learn more about corporate sustainability
To learn about CSR and apply what I learned, particularly for the environmental pillar of sustainable development.
I am interested in corporate environmental management.
I took this course because I plan to work in CSR in the future.
To learn more about what steps a corporation can take to lessen its environmental impact.
I wanted to gain an insight into the field of CSR and how corporations deal with sustainability. I was also looking for some case study based learning.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Same as question 20
No, it seemed very hypothetical and did not seem to be something I could take with me to my job after grad school.
No.
No. Similar to answer above.
Yes, but I feel that I could gained more if I am better involved.
Yes
While I learned basic business knowledge (porter's 5 forces), and a lot about the evolution of corporate sustainability theory, I did not learn about how to apply these skills, which I was expecting.

Overall yes. I came out of the course with a good understanding of the frameworks taught in class (five forces, shared value, etc.) The assignments and final project helped us understand how to apply these frameworks. However I didn't learn as much business strategy as I had hoped. Since most of the students in this class have more environmental background than business, it may have been better to have more "pure" business strategy content.

For the most part, yes. I would have liked to get a bit deeper into the material, and felt that some of the lectures were a bit repetitive of assigned readings. I would have also liked to have been pushed further on the final project. Given the amount of time and the fact that we were working in groups, I think that with more prodding, we could have produced more robust final presentations and power points.
Generally, yes. This is a great overview (a lot of theory) of CSR and corporate environmental management. I learned a lot.
Mostly.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I liked the group-work. I feel there was meaningful exchange between team members based on our different backgrounds.Should continue to do this.
I had a great group to work with. The competitive entry for this class led to having very qualified classmates with interesting backgrounds and experience which I appreciated.

I did a majority of the work in both group projects I did for the class, both of which had 4 group members each. This was disappointing as I had to pull more than my fair share of the weight. I'm not sure what a good solution is to that problem, other than hoping for group members who are willing to put in more time and effort.
It was nice to share knowledge with students of different background, but it seems that we spent too much time on it because of low efficiency.
One of the worst group experiences I've ever had.

Team members for client project were not on the same page with widely varying levels of interest and commitment to the project. Feedback from teaching staff was limited, yet it was briefly communicated to us that our project was under extra scrutiny.

THough sometimes it was hard to coordinate meeting times for my group, the team worked very well together. We were working for a client, so we were able to really dive deeper and implement the ideas we learned about in class to real-life applications.

I was lucky to be in a group that worked well together and everybody was serious and hardworking. Still, the group work took a lot of time. My advice to future students is to start early and ask for advice from the professors and TAs early so that you have a good direction for your project. In addition if you don't have a client or can't contact the company you're studying, reach out to alums who are working in the industry. Talking to them is a much more efficient and effective way to learn about the industry than just doing online research.

It spread out the work in a way that somewhat limited opportunities to delve into the various aspects of the final project prompt, but also was nice in that it was a light end to the semester, work-wise.
Advantages were learning from my peers. Disadvantages were that not everyone did an equal amount of work.
The group project was interesting.
Advantages: learning from peers; distribution of workload. Disadvantage: Free-riding.
Advantages: great discussions, fun to bring ideas and experiences together, I also enjoyed the presentations. Disadvantages: there were a few scheduling difficulties at times.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: There is a considerable amount of theoretical component in this course. A practitioner may find his/herself impatient in the face of this sometimes. But in the end it helps to expand your way of thinking about CEMS.
I would not advise other students to take this course due to the comments above.
Don't

Review the full syllabus beforehand and see if the material is related to your interests. This course will be especially valuable if you would rather gain access to theoretical framework for how to think about corporate environmental management, but less so if you're looking to learn about how to apply corporate management practices to firms.

First, this is more of a theoretical than an applied course. If it is team taught, research both professors and their teaching styles/research. Also, you will get the most out of this class if your final project has a client.

The group work for the final project took a lot of time. My advice to future students is to start early and ask for advice from the professors and TAs early so that you have a good direction for your project. In addition if you don't have a client or can't contact the company you're studying, reach out to alums who are working in the industry. Talking to them is a much more efficient and effective way to learn about the industry than just doing online research.
If you are planning to work in the corporate space, I would recommend taking this class. It provides a great overview of corporate environmental management, complemented by great guest lectures.
Know what you want to get out of it before taking it.

It is a great course to get an overview of CSR and see what companies are currently doing in the field of sustainability. The guest lecturers are also great and often come from industry firms that do excellent sustainability work.
